generation: Another week has flown by. I drove past the new house yesterday, and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing—I'm so excited! If all goes well, we’ll be set to close a week from Wednesday. I stayed up until after 3:00 AM last night watching movies with Bethany. We’ve been watching a lot of films lately. Here’s my rundown: last night, we watched *Thirteen*, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better than I expected. Then we watched *Gigli*—yes, it was just as bad as the reviews claimed, but we had to see for ourselves.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone full of repeats, but now there are two great new shows I’ve been watching religiously. *Blow Out*—the gayest concept ever with zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist Jonathan Antin wants to open a second location of his popular West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Normally, I wouldn’t care, but as I flipped through channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan—equally narcissistic and dull—standing in an empty space on Rodeo Dr., declaring (loudly), "I’m going to build the greatest salon in history!" I was hooked. Not since *Rocco* has such a moron made for compelling TV.

What a week... My right shoulder has tendonitis. It's right under my shoulder blade, so moving my arm too much—especially while using a computer mouse—is agonizing. I can barely move it now after updating my website and working online. Finding the strength to draw is difficult, and lack of sleep worsens the pain. I'm not too happy right now, but I'll recover. My mom's surgery went well. Her eyesight has improved slightly—she can see fuzzy shapes and colors—but she's still mostly blind. Hopefully, her vision will fully return soon.

Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how quickly the simplest things can become an ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet strangers can be for no reason other than kindness. Trust me, it wasn’t like they were trying to get into my pants—I had kid drool all over me and wore my 'wash-day' outfit. Also, I’m not entirely sure I’ll ever bathe again, so there wasn’t even an olfactory incentive! Right now, I’m composing a post while watching No Doubt’s music videos, all from my desk.

"It's 11:14 PM MST, and here I sit in my bedroom repairing the personnel director's computer from work. I don’t mind doing it, but I often wonder how frequently I end up fixing someone else's device as a favor. I’m happy to help, but when does it cross into being taken advantage of? The past few weeks, I’ve stayed up late reading, so I’d hoped to turn in early—until I realized I should return this computer promptly. *Laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So tonight, I’m rewatching *Joe Schmo 2*.

Remind me, what did I write about before this? Or, a continuation of the 'Is this a date?' saga. After the awkward lunch, my confidence wavered, and I forgot to share a key detail. Before Pat arrived, Dustin started praising him, mentioning how he’s trying to find him a girlfriend. I listened, nodding, realizing we were focusing more on setting Pat up than having a normal conversation with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, glanced in the mirror, and wondered: Am I being pawned off to the other guy? Is this what’s happening now?

I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually, I'd like each and every person in the world to consider their choices before getting out of bed in the morning, and commit to staying thoughtful all day. If they're unwilling to do so, I'd very much prefer they climb back into bed and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No, I'm not the smartest person in the world... but I'm not discussing complex matters, so I believe it's fair to criticize the willfully ignorant. Let's see if I can focus this rant on a few specific types—we'll save the rest for another day. Sound good? Great.

'She's saying I'm on the run, I'm chasing guys for fun' ~The Offspring. Haven’t updated in a while, but not much to share. Went to The Cove to see Supernothing—they were great as always, and got to hang with Tiago :-). Saturday: work, then out with Joe and Rach, met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. Got home around 11:45 PM and woke up at 6:45 AM for a meet. Arrived slightly late, but it went well—full routine on floor (no falls!), second on floor and vault, third on beam. Do you ever have one of those moments when you pause to reflect on life? Like when you're sitting in math class, bored out of your mind, and you wonder what exactly happens in your brain to make you understand math? Then you realize you exist, stuck in math class, and question why. Suddenly, it dawns on you how incredible existence is—only to recognize how absurd this train of thought is. Ever experienced that? I despise it. You know what else I hate? Block schedules. Who thought that was a good idea? Sitting through a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is clearly cruel and unusual punishment.

I think that **monopoly** has run **its** course in my life, and I vow to never lay my hands on that **cursed** iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few **dollars** and won the **farcical** game—or maybe I let him win, **since** he’s leaving in a few hours and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. **However** the story goes, it can't compare to this **Texas-sized** headache I have **now**. I’ve taken some Aleve, and it’s **working**—all I need now is some well-deserved R&R. **"Your telephone’s the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck..." —At the Drive-In"**

Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from Indiana. I’ll need to be selective about what I write because I could easily take up too much time and space, and I’m just exhausted. First, I have to say camp was incredible—even better than I expected. God’s been doing amazing things in my life lately, and it’s truly wonderful. I’ve turned over a new leaf, I suppose, but anyway, back to the beginning. We arrived at the Twiggs’ house on Friday evening and stayed until we left for camp on Monday. Most of our time was spent at the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watching movies.

Today is my last day of summer vacation! Waaaaaa! And I have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but I'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery—basically any synonym for 'hell no, I don't wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new challenge for me. As a perfectionist, I love excelling at everything I do. But starting new things is tough. I hate being a pawn (like I told Cassie: 'I'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and I hate not knowing what's going on.

Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had warned, as early as 1996, about the potential rise of a 'third Islamic state' in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the incumbent Governor of Uttar Pradesh, predicted this grave threat in a series of articles published in *The Hindustan Times* back in 1996. Shourie raises a pertinent question: Does knowing that he—and not I, let alone Mr. Advani—wrote these warnings lend them credibility? Or does one dismiss him as a closet communalist, unfit to continue as Governor, simply because of his consistent stance?

Attitude: bored. Mood: indifferent, but looking forward to tonight. It’s been a long, hard day in the trenches today, folks—almost no time to write anything for you readers. However, it’s great to see Tigger (now Akcron) taking up the reins herself, making an appearance, and discussing things. Not much to say otherwise. Yesterday was Shakespeare on the Green—a lovely play, though I had to leave before the final curtain, which was disappointing. Hopefully someday I’ll see an entire Shakespeare production. But I digress. Akcron is right about the shower issues—it’s terrible. As for laughing at her in the shower, you must admit, the expressions people make while enduring self-torture can be quite amusing.

All of a sudden, for the past two days, I have been overwhelmed by terrible exhaustion—bone-deep fatigue. Last evening, I went home and slept until my mother called around eight thirty. When I woke, it was dark, and without lights, I struggled to grasp the time or date for a moment—just her voice in the darkness as I fumbled with reality. Wonder why I'm so drained... Lovely weather this morning. It drizzled when I arrived, though I hear Calcutta has had rain for three days.

Last night was the worst. I discarded the sweater I was knitting after completing about 14 inches. I lost roughly $10 worth of yarn (at $8 per skein). By the time I reached the armholes, there were too many stitches, and the mohair kept tangling as I worked, making frogging ineffective. The yarn kept breaking. Uncharacteristically, I didn’t even swear—just gloomily unraveled it while listening to *Sex and the City* season two (thanks, library!). Eventually, I gave up and tossed it. I guess I learned a lot from this sweater attempt.

Last night in class, we discussed that week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World*, by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores “implacement,” while the second examines “displacement.” Casey argues that our contemporary world prioritizes time as the organizing force—running out of time, saving time, being just in time. He suggests that centering culture around place fosters a more grounded community. (This is a rough summary, in case my professor or classmates read this.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly captivated me.

Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to create those vibrant colours, there should be a warning: may make your life slightly bizarre. While laughter is wonderful, one wonders if we would have ended up on that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not eaten them earlier. Finding ourselves outside a sadly closed bar, we paused to flip through an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the mail. Lucky we did. Who could have guessed that within its pages lay the deals of a lifetime? Certainly not me. Here are just a few: buy 36 permanent markers, get a stunt kite. Purchase 30 lever arch files, receive a barbecue.

Currently listening to: *The Little Drummer Boy* by Stevan Pasero... Now, onto my post... Senate Republicans—hands up, who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations marathon last week? I know I didn’t. Well, fine—I tuned in briefly. The whole spectacle was orchestrated by Republicans who, furious that Democrats wouldn’t rubber-stamp four of Bush’s extreme nominees, staged a multi-day tantrum to score political points. Never mind that Democrats have already approved 168 of Bush’s judicial picks—nooo, that’s insufficient for power-hungry Republicans who somehow believe they have a mandate for this absurdity.

This was a great weekend. I enjoyed a lot of god's green leaf, and after a long time, I listened to Nevermore (something I should have started much earlier) and read extensively. I finished three books—Bruce Sterling's *Heavy Weather*, Larry Niven's *World of Ptavvs*, and Octavia Butler's *Parable of the Sower*. *Heavy Weather* was an engaging cyberpunk adventure set in a near-future USA, ravaged by global warming and chaos. Though clever, well-paced, and convincing, I didn't come away with any profound impressions of the story or characters. Not that they aren't well-crafted and vivid—it's a good book, just not a great one.

Because this is the aftermath. The first week back from practicum was a struggle, but it wasn't until the second week that the smoke truly began to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic now coming to light. I was overwhelmed, but meeting with the course coordinator helped me release my burden, preventing another student from enduring such a pedagogically deficient practicum school. Yesterday (Monday), I encountered another distressed classmate determined to warn the next student assigned to her school. I calmed her, suggesting we approach the administrator first.

Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for stress-relieving activities. I've discovered that I'm terrible at 8-ball and ping pong! Rick (the Canuck) beats me regularly—we have a ping pong table in the front lobby, perfect for a quick game. Last night I joined an 8-ball tournament at the Hot Spot (our recreation tent, complete with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, dartboard, and the ever-present ping pong table). I was doing well in my first game—until I scratched on the eight ball. Still, I had a great time, especially with the two Dutch soldiers who joined the tournament.

Fall 1974: I was attempting—for what felt like the 13th time—to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I hate math. I’m math-phobic. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I set my book aside and went to answer it. No one was there. Perfect. I returned to my studies, and just as a glimmer of understanding surfaced in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam—just like that, my breakthrough vanished. I checked the door, and once again, no one was there. Exactly what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited prankster.

This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent Tuesday through Thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade-level team, which are important factors as I spend countless hours preparing my room for this year. Had I known about the move before the school year ended, I would have discarded many of the unused books and supplies. Unfortunately, I brought everything with me. This week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging extensively. I must thank my teammate Jill for her invaluable help. She was still teaching this month in my old room, so she and her wonderful students moved nearly my entire classroom for me!

I loved you deeply, and to this day the feeling lingers in my heart. Forever will I remember those fleeting nights we shared, hearts and limbs entwined in a soulful embrace, bathed in the salty darkness of a beachside evening... Or a kiss beneath the rain. Whenever I feel the sharp ache of longing, you will be there. That fragment of you... Still bleeding the eternal love that once filled me... And endures. .. For heri

I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting feels very wrong to me. Or rather, the article I'm working on and its consequences don't sit well with me. Perhaps it's because I lack conviction, unable to fully grasp its essence—the underlying angst, the relentless passion needed to question. I grew up in a country where asking questions was forbidden. Truly, you just didn't. They'd shoot you for that. They'd jail you under internal security acts. I'm unaccustomed to this freedom of speech...unused to voicing doubts openly. Admittedly, I'm not the easiest person to get along with.

We had an outing yesterday with my colleagues from the bank. We went to Guintubdan, La Carlota—a first-time experience for most of us. We trekked to the falls, a roughly 30-minute walk that left us breathless. Whew! But we made it. The water was icy cold, numbing our bodies. We stayed less than an hour before heading to nearby waterfalls after another 30-minute trek. The effort was worth it—the falls were serene, and the scenery truly breathtaking. It felt like becoming one with nature. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth. The chilly air and water were so soothing, they could lull you to sleep.

Well, I’m sure my sisters are drunk off their butts. Today was Pride in San Diego. I know my sisters—when it’s drinking time, it’s drinking time. It’s the one thing I didn’t get from the Buenviajes: the urge to drink. There are few times I don’t mind drinking, but let’s just say they’re very rare. We have a month left before Ed leaves. I think it’s starting to sink in for Ed and for all of us. It sunk in for me long ago. I just hope Ed will be here for Bailey’s surgery. We’ve been monitoring his swelling, and there’s definitely quite a bit.

On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, thinking the fireman's Easter egg hunt started at 11 AM. It turned out it was on Friday. Thankfully, I brought a bag of eggs just in case, so Connor had a great time hunting for them in the park. Sunday morning, he woke up thrilled that the Easter Bunny had visited. Nothing beats seeing the excitement on your child's face. After the egg hunt, we all attended church. While the Easter Bunny is fun, we ensure our kids understand the holiday's true meaning. This was Megan's first Easter, and she looked adorable in her denim dress and stockings!

GOP faces criticism after recruitment tactics at naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville prompt relocation plans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the event appeared routine, with nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Before departing on June 29, attendees were directed to a voter registration table—a common practice. However, this table stood out: Republican volunteers distributed forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked, automatically enrolling new voters as GOP members. Linda Cross, present to witness her husband Dario Cruz’s oath, found the situation suspicious.

I will coordinate with 2 onsite coordinators and 8 team members. Currently, I’m busy with KT plans since another project with a team size of 8 will assist us in the next release, as it’s going to be significant. So it’s not really hooky, but I’ve been accumulating sub-days and decided to cash one in today—Wednesday the 10th in Japan (the post-time shows the U.S. date, so it’s technically incorrect)—so I can just goof off for a couple of days. Nothing like 48 hours of daydreaming to restore one’s creative energy. I have it good for a foreigner, and my timing was perfect, too. The illustration part is the icing on the cake. I’d probably complain more if that hadn’t fallen into my lap. I know I’m getting ripped off, though. I’m not blind to that fact. Getting hungry. Might grab some Mexican food at Speakeasy, the "American-style" diner across from the post office in my little prefecture.

I have always prided myself on making everyone who frequents Casa Pescatore as comfortable as possible. I want them to feel at home, just as they would in their own residence. Yesterday, I hope I succeeded. The crowd gathered on Perry Ave with what many considered 'extreme prejudice.' At 4:30 PM, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, and I had prepared all the food while the bells rang wildly. Before I could blink, my best friend from Florida walked through the door, bringing a smile to my face. I missed that guy so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along. She’s expecting, and this is the closest I’ll get to being an uncle. I spoiled her with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.

I liked the idea of that as an offense—perhaps it could've been a way to avoid being burned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I've hesitated to engage in certain discussions, especially those about flags, but since I initiated the topic (not the flag-burning), I should probably comment. Firstly, I believe outlawing flag-burning is absurd. The instant you grant any symbol automatic reverence and protection, you take a small but crucial step toward totalitarianism. Symbols are fickle—they don’t inherently represent anything; their meaning lies in perception and interpretation.

Prom is tomorrow... I hope it’s gonna be fun. That’s all I ask. Rob arrives May 14th... Yeah, three weeks from today... Oh god, I think I’m giving myself an ulcer just thinking about it. But I’m so excited to see him—scared, yes, but très excited. The Leafs played last night... But since Calgary was playing at the same time and I’m out on the West Coast... I had to watch the Calgary game, not the Leafs’... Which is alright, I guess... Considering my Leafs lost... And that makes me sad. But Philly’s a good team... So... I still have bragging rights—they made it farther than the damn Canucks! Today is a crazy day...

Okay, so I have yet to see what my blog will actually look like, but this seems like the place to start. I’m not entirely sure what will unfold here—whether I’ll take to it or not—but since I spend so much time in front of a screen, I might as well make good use of it by sharing the whirlwind of thoughts, or rather, the stumbling ideas, in my head. I was inspired by a blogger (whom I’ve never met), who kept us intimately updated about her daily life while also entertaining us...

1. Everyone has a favorite movie or series—mine is the *Evil Dead* franchise. (In case it wasn’t obvious, I own one of the largest collections of memorabilia from those films.)  
2. Can you play an instrument? Bass guitar—and yes, I absolutely rock.  
3. Biggest money-wasting vice? Either my compulsive DVD purchases or splurging on new tech.  
4. Any phobias, allergies, or compulsive behaviors? None, none, and I *must* organize my wallet’s bills from smallest to largest at all times.  
5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if it could? Because I said so.

Hello, so I saw *Troy* tonight with my family...I wasn’t impressed. I'm too tired to delve into specifics, but it did have potential. However, too much effort went into the set (which was magnificent) and not enough into crafting a cohesive tone or theme. It retold the story but wasn’t gripping, and I didn’t gain much from watching it. The character development was weak. Additionally, the score felt poor—basically a *Gladiator* knock-off. *Gladiator* used a moaning woman’s vocals effectively, complementing its gripping narrative.

Urllink extends a warm welcome to the newest atom/rdf/rss reader on the block: PulpFiction 1.0 from Freshly Squeezed Software. It offers plenty of native app features. Note that it isn't free, as this remains a hot topic online. You can test it for 15 days before deciding to switch back or purchase it for $25. A standout feature is how each post functions as an independent entity—movable, storable, labelable, and deletable. This could greatly benefit news trackers. As expected, it supports OPML import and export.

Today, I miss my sister terribly—it feels strange not having her around, even if she could be a bit irritating (just joking!). Though she was only here for a week, her presence was truly felt, in the best way. Working on the scrapbook from our trip to Tasmania brings back fond memories of such a recent time—just last week, in fact. Perhaps it’s knowing I won’t see her for a while, especially with her move to Bristol in September or October. On a deeper level, she was my connection to family back home. Oh, how I miss them all. Tomorrow begins a new term. How did the holidays pass so quickly?

Ever have one of those days when you just don’t know what the... What the... Anything? No? Well, then you should skip the rest of this because it won’t make sense to you. To those continuing, I offer this observation: *Sometimes I wish I’d been given the manual.* Manuals, if done right, tell you: what things are for, what they can do, how they work, what happens if you press button X or Y, what to do when things go wrong, and the contact details of the all-knowing guru who can fix anything—very useful. Sadly, I didn’t get one with me.

And there's nothing wrong with PCs—if I were a full-bore gamer with time to spare, I’d certainly have a PC system for the wealth of available games. Though aside from a few unique titles, that huge wall of games at CompUSA starts feeling repetitive after a while—at first I’m envious, then I notice it’s mostly different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy titles, simulations. There are so many variations of Age of Empires it becomes comical. AOE—with orcs! AOE—with spaceships! AOE—with fuzzy wombats! It’s like those endless movie trailers that begin with the line: "In a world...

Many unique weapons (a key distinction from Borderlands' RNG-based approach) remain useful throughout. The music is excellent, particularly the main theme and Stan Bush's tracks.

So many things were done wrong. I don’t even know how to begin this review. This all relates to my career. My player is an outside scorer, a PG, 1.71m tall, with maxed stats and all necessary perks. Now, tell me why shooting skill depends on height? Why can’t someone who’s 1.74m be as good at shooting as someone who’s 1.71m? I’m 1.87m in real life, created my first player at this height, and realized I couldn’t exceed an 89 rating. Why? That’s pure discrimination! And why doesn’t the game warn me before I create a character or even when I hit the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?

I think this Assassin's Creed nailed the mechanics across all fronts (ship battles, sailing, fishing, parkour, etc.). I felt much more connected to this character as well. The story starts out rough but improves significantly as you progress (a trend I've noticed in every AC game). Edward was a fascinating protagonist, and the side characters were equally compelling. The collectibles in this installment felt meaningful—something I never experienced in previous games, perhaps because they served a greater purpose. While optional, collecting them was enjoyable and rewarded players fairly.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn’t terrible. The gunplay is decent if you can afford upgrades, which is my main complaint—it’s pay-to-win. Beyond that, the game is enjoyable, with a fun hardsuit and innovative HRV. I’d choose this over any Call of Duty, but its pay-to-win model is off-putting. If you’re fine with this approach, enjoy. But if you dislike pay-to-win games like me, skip it—it’s not for us.

While not perfect, this game has been incredibly enjoyable. The save system and risk of sudden death can be frustrating. I'm on my first playthrough and lost my main character around hour 10 of 20. I would’ve loved a save to reload at that point. Since then, I’ve used a third-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. The aiming reticle is too small, and the zoom feels underpowered. Despite these flaws, it’s been a blast. I’m not usually a zombie fan, but the mix of strategy, missions, and first-person combat is fantastic. I play it whenever I can—just one more mission, one more supply run, or escaping to safety before quitting.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I must say this one fits perfectly. The number of units is impressive—not sure exactly how many, but there's a ton! The graphics are stunning, sounds are excellent, and the gameplay is epic. The in-game chat box on the main menu is very entertaining too—no joke. However, if you think this game is 'easy' or are new to strategy games, it may take time to master. Don’t get frustrated—you’ll lose many units. Just plan ahead, always bring anti-air and anti-tank.

I was initially biased against this game and hesitated to buy it. The portal gun concept seemed odd, despite my love for sci-fi. Boy, was I wrong. The humor and voice acting are phenomenal—just amazing. It’s occasionally cheesy, but each character has a distinct personality and sense of humor. The level design is brilliant. By the way, I haven’t played the first Portal game yet, but I plan to when I have time. I wouldn’t have tried it if I hadn’t played the sequel.

"Let’s begin with the pros (+) and cons (-), followed by my thoughts on this game.

+ Great story

Now for my thoughts: I adore this game. It’s one of the best RPGs—or games in general—I’ve ever played. If you’re an RPG fan, you likely own it already.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just for the five-minute *Transformers* cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and others return, instantly recognizable. The iconic transformation sound remains. Graphically, the cel-shaded style is flawless, authentically Generation One. Beyond nostalgia, it's genuinely fun. The combat mechanics excel—transforming mid-fight is essential, seamlessly integrated into combos, setting it apart from High Moon's *War for/Fall of Cybertron*. Another standout is the emphasis on melee, though some foes (e.g., Seekers) demand ranged attacks.

I downloaded the game and played it briefly, but it was underwhelming. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing due to a bug. After accepting the updated terms of service, the prompt kept reappearing until I restarted the client. While manageable, why force a link between Steam and GFace accounts for DLC? It’s irreversible, granting a company I don’t trust access to my Steam data. The game itself is mediocre—a clear COD clone with worse gunplay. How is that even possible?

4K at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo An excellent port and a great entry point for newcomers to the series. Just note there's plenty of (skippable) dialogue. As usual, a gamepad is recommended, but I had no issues with a keyboard/mouse setup—both fully rebindable. The price is fair, and I wouldn't regret the purchase. Over half the DLC is included free, offering plenty of content. Highly recommended for JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, as long as you don't mind slower pacing. Cheers. No-commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues even at launch, and after all these updates it runs smoothly. Imo, this is a truly great and fun game, though the format may be slightly annoying (where the free-roam city repopulates with enemies after story progress). I especially loved the 'dual play' segments (featuring Batman + another character), and the option to use a controller for most gameplay while switching to mouse and keyboard for tank battles was fantastic. Driving the Batmobile through the city, particularly during APC chases, becomes incredibly satisfying once you learn to use the brakes for sharp turns—mastering this makes cruising through Gotham an absolute joy!

Damn fine AAA FPS shooter—that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays great—stellar mechanics, a compelling story, memorable characters, flawless voice acting, and a killer soundtrack. Not for the faint-hearted, though—some cutscenes are brutally vivid. But when a game excels overall, flaws stand out:  
- No SLI support—why? I shelved it until upgrading my GPU, as it ran poorly on my old GTX 590. A solid single-GPU card is a must.  
- Frustratingly small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language—I am Dutch. Please excuse any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this fantastic game. I’ll break it down into categories:  

- **Graphics**  
- **Controls**  
- **Sound**  
- **Gameplay**  
- **Replayability**  

**Graphics**: The game features a comic-like style. The visuals are sleek, avoiding unnecessary details, with appealing color schemes that suit the game perfectly. You can set the graphics to 'high' without straining your system. I run it on an i5 Pentium processor, NVIDIA GeForce 710M, 8GB RAM (Windows 8.1), and it runs smoothly.  

**Controls**: The game supports both keyboard/mouse and an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I’ve put into this game that I enjoy it. This is everything I hoped a tactical game from COD would be. But don’t buy it expecting COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter. It’s in a class of its own and should be treated as such. Can’t count how many times I hear new players whine about dying too fast. Oh no, you got shot in the face and died—like that never happens in real life. Edit: I’ve played this game for a while now, invested heavily, and it’s one of the best multiplayer games out there. Perfect when you’re not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm two hours in and absolutely loving this game. It's hilarious. The gameplay is solid, the art design is stunning, the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, the story/world is captivating, and the puzzles are enjoyable. But the standout feature is the comedy. Whether you're an RPG veteran or new to the genre, the humor shines through with clever jokes, parodies, and references. Fans of *Final Fantasy VII* or *X* especially shouldn't miss this—without spoiling anything, I had to pause after two hours just to rest my cheeks from laughing so hard. What a delight so far.

I'm really sorry, I try to support free-to-play games and indie developers, but I didn't enjoy this one. The description seemed perfect for me, but the execution fell flat. I love puzzle and exploration games, yet I found this one unintuitive, and even after checking guides, the gameplay just wasn't fun. It also lacks a pause button—or if it exists, I couldn't find it. Given the timed sequences, this feels like a major oversight. Additionally, the game feels more like cutscenes than gameplay, leaving me waiting impatiently.

This game... Phew, where to even begin. It was absolutely stunning, from the story to the graphics—I was hooked. The narrative wasn’t just any story; it felt like I was living it, unraveling each twist alongside my character. The gameplay was fantastic, and I discovered a lot about myself (mainly my fear of heights, which never bothered me until the ice caverns). My stomach churned the whole time, but I pushed through for Uncle Fred! If you ever release a DLC or sequel, I’d be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thank you to everyone involved—you’ve created a truly beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based strategy game where you build your civilization toward a specific goal or 'victory'. In earlier titles, you progressed through Earth's historical eras, such as the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age. However, this installment takes you to the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I appreciate is 2K's fresh approach, introducing innovative mechanics like the affinity system and orbital layer. My only critique is that these additions can occasionally feel overwhelming. One potential improvement would be incorporating new artwork, particularly in the environments during leader interactions.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: After 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games. It's designed like a survival horror where you must conserve ammo, treat wounds, take pills when infected, etc. Also, the zombies feel natural and are well-animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I'd recommend playing with 1 or 2 friends, but the community is super friendly—you can easily make friends via chat or voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's a shame I can't fully recommend this game, as from the short time I've played, I know I'd be addicted if not for two major issues. No Aussie servers—one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage, causing unbearable lag. Even the offline training mode stuttered and lagged (how does that happen?). Combined with poor ping, it ruins the experience. Everything artifacts excessively—menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never seen this before with my card and suspected my overclock. Returning the GPU to stock settings made no difference.

Very late last night, I finished this. The story isn't particularly deep or compelling, but its storytelling sets it apart. The atmosphere is immersive, and the numerous collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about Batman's world, though the lack of bosses was disappointing. Oh well, future games can address that. The combat offers a fair challenge but leans toward the easier side. Leveling up Batman felt underwhelming. However, upgrading and acquiring gadgets throughout the campaign introduces fresh mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable areas creates a satisfying sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's *The Walking Dead* is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for *To the Moon*! Never before have I been so moved yet fulfilled by something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents storytelling at its finest, and the soundtrack is a charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay isn't the strong point, but the story is so compelling that I didn’t mind at all. Plus, the humor is delightful and never detracts from the narrative's depth... And the *Doctor Who* references are endless.

Bastion is an outstanding game, featuring a captivating storyline. Set after a catastrophic event, you begin rebuilding the bastion. The game offers extensive choice, allowing you to decide what structures to build for an advantage, which weapons to wield, and which upgrades to apply—alongside selecting drinks for bonus effects. The art style and music are exceptional, with vibrant visuals proving the apocalypse need not be bleak. Best of all, the game features dynamic narration based on your actions. For instance, if you swap weapons in the armory, the narrator comments on your new choice.

I originally bought this game during early development, when the only currency was spacebux and there was no 'tech tree.' Back then, the game was great. All the guns were equally overpowered, so imbalance wasn't an issue—anyone could kill anyone at any time. Plus, the game offered unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You'd think a game boasting 'bajillions of guns' would provide more than 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before charging for extras. At one point, I had around 3 pages of guns and was brainstorming new ideas because, for me, that was the fun part.

This game was a surprising gem. While rave reviews can often be misleading, in this case, they truly capture the fun of this neat little game. It blends a classic 2D platformer with a MOBA seamlessly and stylishly. I enjoyed characters I wouldn’t typically favor in other MOBAs. Though I expected this trend to continue, I tried a melee tank anyway—and was pleasantly surprised. I ended up exploring more as they unlocked through gameplay. The art style and interface are oddly charming. Now, I even use a character as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in it for hours. It's been a while since a game has captivated me like this. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are flawless. I eagerly anticipate every battle, and combat is brilliantly optimized. I had doubts about the naval combat system, but it's exhilarating to decimate multiple fleets at once! The only way to lose is by failing to retreat. If combat seems overwhelming, just withdraw, regroup, and strike back. Thanks, devs, for an incredible experience!

The reboot of the *Devil May Cry* franchise has introduced significant changes, particularly for the series’ protagonist, Dante. While longtime fans may lament the shift, it ultimately benefits the character; Ninja Theory’s new game proves this. *DmC* serves as an ideal entry point for newcomers, showcasing the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and tracing his evolution into selflessness. The game crafts a clear narrative arc for this new Dante, making him a compelling figure. The story follows him as he confronts the corrupt world he once ignored.

Where do I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, packed with intricate details, and brimming with happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It balances seriousness with humor effortlessly. The character design is impeccable, featuring diverse personalities and hidden depths. What sets it apart from other RPGs is the option to avoid killing anyone—a rare concept in the genre. Drawing heavy inspiration from *EarthBound*, one of the finest RPGs I’ve encountered, its quality is undeniable. Plus, it boasts the best soundtrack I’ve heard in years.

I recommend this solely because it's free and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. As for me, the 'game' fell flat. Half the story relies on shock value, but I felt neither shocked nor moved. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or it was too simplistic to evoke a reaction. The other half attempts to depict mental decline, exploring obsession, hallucination, depression, and more. Theoretically, it's an interesting concept. However, the 'game' took me just 10 minutes to finish, even while carefully absorbing every detail.

If you can overlook the bugs (I personally encountered only two: one minor and another quite annoying) edit: both issues are resolved—one fix boosted my fps from 60-90 to 80-120—and are seeking a space exploration game, I highly recommend this. Since most reviews focus on specs, here are mine: i5 6600k (~200€), Radeon RX 480 (~200€), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~150€), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€). At ~650€, this setup falls in the mid-range, though admittedly, it's fairly new. Nearly constant 60+ fps on high settings with Vsync enabled. I’m baffled by 90% of comments claiming their overpowered rigs barely hit 20fps.

Remember *Age of Mythology*? Yeah, it's been that long since we've seen an RTS game of such caliber. *Divinity: Dragon Commander* comes awfully close to being my personal favorite. Combine this with a grand strategy mode akin to *Risk*, and it truly hits the mark. I try not to be overly biased, but the fact that you can transform into a dragon—supporting troops, attacking, and even managing unit production—is incredible. Nowadays, I do enjoy complex RTS games like *Civ V*. However, such titles often cram intricate mechanics, charts, and resources into a single overwhelming experience.

Undertale combines its elements to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title, and the music is charming, but together they craft truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script ranges from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes simultaneously, while subverting RPG tropes. And this is without even mentioning the world, characters, story, or gameplay... I could write pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours before your death, play this game.

I’ve only had this game for a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The devs are highly active in the community, evident in discussion forums and dev diaries. There’s a fairly steep learning curve to the mechanics, which I’m still mastering, but this strategic depth offers countless ways to achieve goals and exploit situations. The game feels almost infinitely replayable. I’m drawn into every session, no matter how the playthrough unfolds.

Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those initial enjoyable hours, you'll notice the only thing left is repetitive combat, enemies, and gameplay. The major highlight is the developers' dedication, with frequent updates that introduce sweeping system changes, new warframes, and other tweaks. It's a solid casual game, though unlikely to hold your attention beyond a few months unless you enjoy grinding. The best part is that it's free, so I'd recommend giving it a try. If you're looking for a quick fix, it's worth checking out.

This game is so... very... boring. I bought it because I believed it was a PC version of *Katamari Damacy*, a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Sadly, it’s far from it. In this game, you go around absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger. But the gameplay lacks smoothness, the levels are uninspired, and the overall experience feels like a surreal horror show—not an entertaining one, but one that leaves you depressed and questioning existence. Every 'living' creature, from small pets to humans, makes me wonder if the developers had a fascination with taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As someone very interested in politics, I was intrigued by this game when I first heard about it. I thought, *Wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!* Well, it really wasn't. The game starts by making you pick a side: Republican or Democrat—no independent or third-party option. A little disappointed but still optimistic, I carried on to see what I could do. I will give the game credit: the character customization, though limited, is pretty fun to experiment with. It's the only time you can choose whether to wear your head in a campaign. Literally.

Fallout 3’s story was superior. Settlements disrupt the narrative, making you resent managing them instead of enjoying the plot. Some keys are hardcoded and unchangeable. Bugs are rampant—my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, forcing me to use console commands. Power armor requires no effort; it’s handed to you early, and cores are abundant, diminishing its value. The story is mediocre, as is most of the game, though it’s more stable than Fallout 3. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. New Vegas? No. This title was vastly overhyped for its lackluster quality.

English - 73 minutes played. OMFG, just an hour in and it's awesome! Some guns are OP, and matchmaking can be unfair, but hey, BF3's is worse. Newbies face high-level players who weren’t real humans—shoot them in the face and nothing happens!

It's not hard for me to see why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing, I have a Vive and prefer playing room-scale games with motion controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe-inspiring in its vast universe, but I also found that scale hindered my enjoyment. The steep learning curve and time required to do anything engaging early on were too much for me. Perhaps with more patience and gaming time, it would appeal to me. But I lack both, and there are many other VR games I'd rather play.

Hands down my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. A single hit to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons is almost always fatal unless it barely grazes you. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are essential to stay on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. Reloading halfway through your magazine leaves you with a pouch full of partially spent mags. You can't sprint indefinitely—prolonged running impairs your aim as you gasp for breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to stabilize your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start by saying I did not purchase EU when it first released and got it on sale, which included EW, so I never experienced the issues some claim to have had. I loved that game—it was unforgiving early on but rewarding when done right. As for XCOM 2, I love it; the game runs well for me on medium with a GTX 560 (2GB VRAM). Initially set to high, it ran sluggishly but remained playable. Dropping to medium smoothed it out. I’m not sure if I’m just lucky with game issues, but many negative reviews sound like they come from overly entitled people.

+RPG leveling +Wide variety of ship types +Physics-based movement for ships and projectiles/missiles +Easy-to-learn resource management +Dark humor -Grind-intensive (if underutilizing civilian stations) -Subpar AI teammates -Limited equipment variety -Few leveling skill options (no branching)  

Listen, this game is incredibly fun. Despite the drawbacks listed above, it offers enough variety and strategy to keep you engaged. It starts fast and only gets better. Even with limited equipment, there’s always a new ship to unlock or skill to upgrade. Mods significantly extend the game’s lifespan—Fight for Universe is the standout, but Big Fight for Beef is also excellent.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as more than 2,000 business and political figures from across the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over five days, they will address issues ranging from China's economic influence to Iraq's future following this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the 20+ heads of state attending. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued. Anti-globalization activists have canceled a planned weekend demonstration. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to coincide with the WEF's more exclusive event in Davos.

Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal. Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to resolve a dispute over a potential takeover. The deadline marks when Fiat gains the right to sell its car division to GM, part of a 2000 alliance. GM, struggling with losses in Europe, no longer wants the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, following Monday's 4% rise on payout hopes. The US firm is offering around $2bn (£1.06bn) to exit the agreement. It claims the deal was voided when Fiat sold its finance arm and diluted GM's stake. The 2000 deal emerged from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, has criticised the Iraq War, stating that billions spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty. He made these remarks on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance during his Christmas midnight mass. In his Christmas message, the cardinal denounced the war as a "terrible" waste of resources. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have voiced opposition to the conflict. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's *Thought for the Day*, he lamented that "billions" were spent on war instead of lifting people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." The cardinal urged that 2005 should be the year to campaign to "make poverty history.

British stars were denied major Oscars as UK hopes of winning top awards were dashed. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's *Vera Drake* missed out on director and screenplay honors, and star Imelda Staunton also went unrecognized. Kate Winslet lost the Best Actress category to Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo failed to secure Best Supporting Actor awards. The UK’s Andrea Arnold claimed the Short Film prize for her gritty drama *Wasp*. Arnold, a former host of children's shows *Number 73* and *Motormouth* in the 1980s, called the win "totally overwhelming." *Wasp* follows a struggling single mother, triumphing over films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Halloween writer Debra Hill dies. Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic *Halloween*, has passed away in Los Angeles at age 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, starring Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it earned over $60 million worldwide—a record for independent films at the time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on *Escape from New York* and *The Fog*. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant, rising through the ranks to become an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a trailblazing woman in film, taking on roles in the 70s typically dominated by men.

Broadband fuels online expression, as fast web access encourages more people to share their thoughts online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and maintain personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. It stated that always-on, high-speed connections are transforming how people use the internet. Over five million UK households now have broadband, and this number is rapidly increasing. The Demos report examined broadband's impact on online behavior. It revealed that more than half of broadband users log on before breakfast. One in five even admitted to waking up at night to browse. Most notably, the report argues broadband is motivating people to engage more actively online.

Yukos Heads Back to US Courts  

Russian oil and gas company Yukos is due in a US court on Thursday as it fights for survival. The firm is being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, seeking to use international law to block the forced sale of its key unit, Yuganskneftegaz. However, the unit was sold for $9.4bn to state-owned Rosneft after the auction was disrupted. Yukos claims the sale violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its shareholders vow to pursue any buyers of its assets through all legal avenues.

Voters flock to the Blog Awards site as voting begins for the annual Bloggies, honoring the best web blogs—online platforms where individuals share their thoughts. Nominations were announced Sunday, but overwhelming traffic temporarily shut down the official site. Weblogs are competing in 30 categories, ranging from top regional blog to best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with a leading US dictionary declaring "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, monitors roughly six million blogs, noting over 12,000 new ones daily. Research by Pew Internet and American Life reveals a blog is created every 5.8 seconds, yet fewer than 40% are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing'—China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to halt construction of one of its giant dams, state media reports. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam continues work on the Xiluodu Dam, according to *Beijing News*. The Xiluodu project is among 30 large-scale constructions suspended due to inadequate environmental reviews. *Beijing News* stated the company may opt to pay a fine instead. The firm has also disregarded orders to stop work at two other sites—the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Power Supply Plant. Only 22 of the 30 projects flagged by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for lacking mandatory impact assessments have complied with shutdown orders.

Man City 0-2 Man Utd: Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points with a hard-fought victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney converted Gary Neville's near-post cross with a low shot, deflected off Richard Dunne, to give United the lead. Seven minutes later, Dunne inadvertently volleyed the ball over David James and into his own net. Steve McManaman squandered City's best chance, shooting wide from close range in the first half. United initially seemed unlikely to secure the win needed to stay in the title race, as their play lacked fluidity. They created only one clear opportunity—a Paul Scholes header over the bar—in the opening 45 minutes.

Wales 'must learn health lessons'—the new Health Minister for Wales says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists. Dr. Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the role after Jane Hutt was dismissed, acknowledged "big challenges" but maintained the "essentials" were in place. Both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats argued Dr. Gibbons must revise policy. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, stating waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, formerly a GP in Blaengwynfi in the Upper Afan Valley before becoming AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff sought stability after "tremendous change and reform." One of Ms. Hutt's greatest challenges during her five-and-a-half-year tenure as the Assembly's first Health Minister was Wales' lengthy waiting lists.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve  
Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' determined performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away game this season, and it was a thrilling match, end-to-end with excellent passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed great character and resilience, and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come, and Villa may have some players back by then." Ferguson also lauded senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who replaced the injured John O'Shea. "Roy brought much-needed composure to the midfield—something no other player offers.

Singer's film to screen at festival  
A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping artist George Michael will premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. *A Different Story* will feature in the Panorama section, running from 10–20 February. The film explores Michael’s career and personal journey, from his Wham! days to recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February, alongside director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute documentary delves into his early years with Wham!, his later career, legal disputes with Sony, and his opposition to the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads enter the US singles chart as digital music downloads are now included in the main ranking for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart incorporates data from download sales, previously tracked separately. Green Day's *Boulevard of Broken Dreams* is number two on Billboard's Pop chart and leads its digital ranking. Download sales will join the UK singles chart later this year. In the US, digital sales already inform Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be combined with physical sales and airplay data for the updated Hot 100. A second new chart—the Pop 100—also merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but limits airplay data to US radio stations playing chart music.

Anti-spam laws hit spammers hard as the net's self-declared spam king seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the man behind OptInRealBig.com and billions of junk emails, claims lawsuits forced his company into Chapter 11. OptInRealBig was battling multiple legal disputes, notably against Microsoft, which seeks millions in damages. The firm stated that filing for Chapter 11 would help resolve its legal issues while continuing operations. Ranked as the world's third-largest spammer by watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for violating anti-spam laws. Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer alleged Richter and his associates sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised addresses across 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini. Tottenham sporting director Frank Arnesen has dismissed claims that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been media speculation that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is completely untrue," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "The only reason for his resignation was personal issues. He recently confided in me, stating this matter was entirely his own." Arnesen admitted he could not clarify the problems that led Santini to leave after just 13 matches. He added: "Jacques never specified the reasons. But I trust his word; we must accept it. I believe we should respect his decision.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and another penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the win. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to hosting England at Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will aim to give coach Matt Williams his first Six Nations win when Italy visit Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

Economic focus for election battle: Britain's economic future will be central to Labour's campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced. He spoke after cabinet members held their final meeting at No. 10 ahead of the expected election announcement. Brown stated voters would acknowledge Labour's record of stability and growth, pledging to sustain it. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined plans to address 'yob culture,' and the Lib Dems elaborated on proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury urged all parties in an open letter to avoid exploiting public fears on terrorism, asylum, and crime during the campaign.

Brizzel to compete in AAA's in Sheffield. Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European Indoor hopefuls participating in this weekend's AAA Championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy aims to secure his spot in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has excelled on the European circuit recently. He ranks among the fastest 800m runners this winter and appears certain for Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European Championships. Carroll is currently third in the world 3000m rankings, with Cragg holding the top position.

Robinson aims for dual-code success as England rugby union captain Jason Robinson targets victory over Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 14:30 GMT. At 18:15 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team faces Australia in the Tri-Nations final. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England could secure their third autumn international win after victories over Canada and South Africa, while avenging June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain may end 34 years of losses against Australia with victory at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid scam: Net users are being warned to avoid a fraudulent website claiming to collect donations for tsunami victims. The site appears credible as it mimics an old version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, DEC has no ties to the fake site and has reported it to the police. This is just one of many scams exploiting goodwill after the tsunami disaster. The link to the site is spread via a spam email currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" and contains the poor grammar and spelling typical of phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone licence bids  
Iraq will invite bids for two telephone licences, aiming to significantly expand nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids are open to local, Arab, and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications stated. The winner will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed-line network, offering voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to raise Iraq's "very low telephone penetration rate from 4.5% to 25% within 10 years." It also seeks to develop a "dynamic and competitive telecommunications sector." Bidding and tender details will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February. A roadshow for investors is also planned in Amman, Jordan.

More women and older adults are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against cyber threats, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware rose by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for cybersecurity firm Preventon, reveals that security awareness is reaching a broader audience. Approximately 40% of home cybersecurity program buyers are retirees, with this figure increasing by an average of 13.2% over the past three years. Notably, more retired women (53%) invested in security software than retired men. The findings highlight shifting stereotypes and demographics among internet users, alongside growing recognition of the heightened risks posed by high-speed broadband connections.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music player can hold up to 10,000 songs, leaving ample space to fill. Increasingly, iPod owners are using that space for audio content created by a diverse range of producers. This trend is called 'podcasting,' championed by former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry. Podcasting derives its name from the Apple iPod, though an iPod isn’t required to create or listen to one. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show, often produced from home. All creators need is a microphone, a PC, and editing software. They upload their shows online, allowing free downloads and listening for audiences worldwide.

Levy wins Whitbread novel prize  
Orange Prize winner Andrea Levy has claimed the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her book *Small Island*. She now leads as the favorite to secure the overall prize after surpassing Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's *The Line of Beauty*. Geraldine McCaughrean has secured the children's fiction award for the third time with *Not the End of the World*. All category winners advance to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which includes a £25,000 prize. A judging panel featuring Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris will convene on 25 January to determine the overall winner, with the announcement following that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has ranked London-based Levy’s novel as the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure firm that purchased its main asset. Yukos has stated it will sue Baikal and others involved in the $20bn sale of Yuganskneftegas for damages. Yukos' US lawyers will push to freeze Baikal's assets after the Russian government disregarded a US court order last week halting the sale. Baikal's background and motives remain unclear. Russian newspapers allege Baikal—which acquired Yuganskneftegas for $9.4bn at a state-backed auction—has strong ties to Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts secured a 2-1 victory over Livingston in their Scottish Cup quarter-final, scoring twice within the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller struck within 60 seconds, heading Jamie McAllister’s free-kick over Colin Meldrum. McAllister added the second, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post. Craig Easton’s late header proved too little for Livingston.  

The opener came after Gus Bahoken fouled Miller 35 yards out. McAllister’s delivery found Miller, who outjumped the defense to loop his header over Meldrum. Minutes later, Mikoliunas sprinted down the right and crossed for McAllister to head home, sealing Hearts' dominance.

Sun offers processing by the hour. Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service enabling customers needing significant computing power to rent it hourly. Sun Grid charges users $1 (53p) per hour for processing and storage on its systems. Grid computing is the latest trend in a company that views computing capacity as vital as hardware and software. Sun compared grid computing to the evolution of electricity. The system may mature like utilities such as power and water, said Sun's COO Jonathan Schwartz. 'Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?' he asked during a webcast for Sun's quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson Issues Warning to Bigots  

Scotland's Justice Minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she intends to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are among a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive’s campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in tackling the issue. However, the minister emphasized that curbing sectarian abuse linked to Old Firm matches remains a priority. Ms. Jamieson spoke ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long tied to sections of both clubs' support has become a key target for the Executive. Last week, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met representatives from both clubs to address the problem.

UK debut for Kevin Spacey movie: Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film *Beyond the Sea* in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife—real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) Headingley Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT. The Tykes have recruited Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen joins from Narbonne. Raphaël Ibañez starts at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also named in the pack, with Kevin Sorrell at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley was cleared to proceed after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an unclear future—the fixed-line phone in your home could soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that increasing numbers of people rely solely on their mobile phones for calls. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use mobiles. While many retain fixed-line phones for lower call charges, most respondents agreed the future is undoubtedly mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research highlighted distinct usage patterns: home phones for longer calls, while mobile conversations were shorter and often with friends. In the UK, 69% of participants still preferred fixed-line phones due to cost savings.

Melzer stuns Agassi as second seed Andre Agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by Jurgen Melzer in the SAP Open quarter-finals. Agassi was repeatedly outmaneuvered by the Austrian's drop shots in San Jose, losing 6-3, 6-1. Defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick rallied to overcome Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Unseeded Cyril Saulnier defeated fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, while Tommy Haas edged past eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi twice in their three meetings. 'I executed my game plan perfectly,' he said. 'Facing Andre is always tough. I wanted to disrupt his rhythm—he makes you chase every ball.'

A group of MPs has intensified pressure on Tony Blair regarding House of Lords reform by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber with 70% elected members. MPs and peers have struggled to agree on reform since 1999, when 600 hereditary members lost their seats. The group believes it can secure support to remove the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government delayed plans to eliminate them, citing opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on reforms. Suggestions indicate Labour’s manifesto may propose changes to the Lords’ powers.

Disappointed Scott in solid start: Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a strong debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the José M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. 'It was a valuable learning experience, and I’m still aiming for a medal next week,' said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who matched the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg took second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his final run. He won his heat in 7.64secs but clocked 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix final.

A U.S. woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a set date. The unnamed Georgia resident claims a chip inside the cartridge falsely signals the printer to refill even when unnecessary. The lawsuit aims to represent all U.S. purchasers of HP inkjet printers since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer company, declined to comment. HP cartridges use chip technology to detect low ink and prompt replacement. However, the suit alleges the chips also deactivate cartridges by a preset date, regardless of ink levels.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast. UK broadcaster Virgin Radio will become the first station globally to deliver radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, collaborating with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on select 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners can download software from Virgin's website to access the service. James Cridland, Virgin Radio's Head of New Media, stated: "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will debut first, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland added: "This app will let anyone, anywhere tune in to Virgin Radio with just their phone.

Roxy Music is set to appear at June's Isle of Wight Festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM have already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, running from 10-12 June. Original members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will perform on the festival's Saturday night. The band is also working on new material in the studio—their first since the 1982 album *Avalon*. Formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year, Roxy Music's first hit was 1972's *Virginia Plain*. Other hits include *Street Life*, *Love Is the Drug*, and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's *Jealous Guy*.

Captains lining up for the aid match include Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, one of four Six Nations skippers selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami complete the Northern lineup. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod MacQueen's Southern Hemisphere side in a tsunami fund-raising clash at Twickenham. 'I'm excited to work with such exceptional players,' he said. The match offers Woodward a chance to evaluate options before naming his British and Irish Lions squad for their summer tour of New Zealand. 'It promises to be a thrilling spectacle,' he added.

Spirit Awards Hail *Sideways* The comedy *Sideways* dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six categories for which it was nominated. It claimed Best Film, while Alexander Payne secured Best Director and Best Screenplay, alongside writing partner Jim Taylor. The film also earned acting honors for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. *Sideways* is favored to perform well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, recognize films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama *Maria Full of Grace*. Moreno is also an Oscar nominee for Best Actress. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for *Maria Full of Grace*.

Prince was crowned the 'top music earner' of 2004, surpassing stars like Madonna and Elton John in *Rolling Stone*'s annual list. The singer earned $56.5 million (£30.4m) from concerts, album sales, and publishing, thanks to his *Musicology* tour and album. Madonna secured second place with $54.9 million (£29.5m) during her global *Re-Invention* tour. Veterans Simon & Garfunkel ranked 10th, earning $24.9 million (£13.4m) from their comeback tour. "Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine noted. His 2004 tour grossed $90.3 million (£48.5m) in ticket sales, and *Musicology* sold 1.9 million copies.

Walmart fights back at critics as two major U.S. companies launch advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behavior. The world's largest retailer placed over 100 full-page ads in national newspapers, addressing criticism over its pay structure, benefits, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is preparing a campaign to counter "false" claims about its product Prozac. Walmart initiated the effort with ads in publications like *The Wall Street Journal*, featuring an open letter from CEO Lee Scott, urging the public to hear the "unfiltered truth." "There are many 'urban legends' circulating about Walmart, but facts are facts.

The Tories outlined policing plans under which local communities would elect their own area police commissioner, as proposed by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard stated the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities but wouldn’t override a chief constable’s duties. The Lib Dems warned the plan could empower extreme groups, while Labour criticized "extravagant" Tory pledges. Responding, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales stressed the need to retain operational independence. Jan Berry remarked: "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every election. These plans could let extreme political views dictate policing on the ground," she cautioned.

At a glance: Tory health checks. The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's an overview of the proposal: Individuals moving to Britain from outside the EU who intend to stay six months or longer—and are from high-TB countries—would require a chest x-ray and further tests if necessary. All non-EU nationals seeking to stay a year or more must undergo a comprehensive medical examination, including screening for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test would result in automatic visa rejection, while other conditions would be assessed individually.
