Paris promise raises Welsh hopes. Has there ever been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? Can Wales' revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? These questions captivate not just Welsh supporters but rugby fans worldwide after a scintillating display. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, part of two Grand Slam-winning sides in the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past thirty years." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try hero, called it "one of the most surreal games I've ever played." A crestfallen French coach, Bernard Laporte, simply noted: "There was a French half and a Welsh half."

Doves soar to UK album summit. Manchester rock band Doves have topped the UK album chart with their new release, *Some Cities*. The trio replace flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at number one. The album follows their single *Black and White Town*, which peaked at number six. R&B star Nelly claims the top single with *Over and Over*, featuring Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, alongside Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, *(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame*, entered at number three, just ahead of Girls Aloud's *Wake Me Up*. Hip-hop artist Akon's *Locked Up* holds number five, while Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs score their second hit at six with *Oh My God*.

Davies favors Gloucester future. Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to remain with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are keen on the 32-year-old, but he prefers to stay put. Davies, a standout in Saturday's RBS Six Nations victory over England, is on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proven his value to the Zurich Premiership side and is expected to secure a new deal next season. The Celtic Warriors' collapse last summer left Davies sidelined, forcing him to accept a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. While he played for the Ospreys at Wales management's request, he admitted before joining Gloucester that he was frustrated with his treatment.

Cabinet anger at Brown’s cash raid: Ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall funds to curb council tax hikes, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr. Raynsford admitted to holding "frank discussions" with colleagues over the move. However, he stressed that councils must maintain quality services without significant tax increases. The central funds form part of a £1bn package to help English local authorities limit next year’s council tax rises below 5%, ahead of a likely general election. Mr. Raynsford noted that nearly all central departments have a stake in well-run local governments.

Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin is looking to Africa, with four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, set to feature in their UEFA Cup campaign. Bnei Sakhnin, the first Arab team to compete in European competition, will face English Premier League side Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, who rose to prominence during the Africa Cup of Nations in Tunisia, played a key role in their 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. After a short spell with South African club Hellenic, he recently moved to Israel. Based near Haifa in Sakhnin, the club won last season’s Israeli Cup and is renowned for its strong ethics and commitment to promoting peace and cooperation in Israel.

New drink limit 'would cut toll': More lives than previously thought could be saved by reducing drink-drive limits by a third, a report states. University College London research suggests lowering the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood would save 65 lives annually. The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, coincide with MPs voting on the government's Road Safety Bill. The bill revises speeding fines but leaves the drink-drive limit unchanged. Transport expert Professor Richard Allsop's research indicates this change would also prevent 230 serious injuries on UK roads compared to 2003, saving £119m yearly. A 1998 Department of Transport estimate projected only 50 lives saved annually.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, while the array design offers a large detection area of 512×512 μm². Rather than sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width—the time required for the voltage to return to baseline. This eliminates the need for power-hungry, bulky analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC, fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS, consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital supply. The system's functionality is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to mitigate the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, assuming AVs would readily accept external control by a central authority is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing scheme to incentivize AVs toward centrally controlled system-optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings, while user-equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) face congestion charges. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization: dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, while the lower level consists of a simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model for mixed AV and HV fleets.

Optomechanics and electromechanics now enable macroscopic mechanical oscillators to be prepared in quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. Beyond pushing larger objects into the quantum regime, this breakthrough supports applications in quantum information processing, communication, and ultra-precise force sensing beyond standard quantum limits. However, the predominantly linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to richer quantum states, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early proposals suggested overcoming this limitation through strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. While experiments have demonstrated quadratic optomechanical coupling, achieving nonclassical states of motion remains elusive.

Online reviews offer product evaluations to help customers make informed decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who employ increasingly sophisticated and powerful spamming strategies to evade detection. Spamming strategies are difficult to capture, as they vary rapidly over time, differ across spammers and target products, and often remain unknown. Moreover, most existing detectors prioritize accuracy, which does not fully align with maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we formulate a minimax game where spammers and detectors compete based on practical goals beyond mere detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game yield stable detectors that remain effective against any mixed spamming strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high-fidelity (UH-fidelity) population transfer in a 3-level quantum system with lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions enabling exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Within this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to simultaneously control transfer fidelity, excited-state population, and robustness. We quantify robustness as the minimum percentile deviation in pulse areas at which infidelity exceeds $10^{-4}$. Our shaped pulses demonstrate superior robustness compared to Gaussian and adiabatically optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we examine the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function for Gaussian mixture models with an arbitrary number of components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even in well-separated mixtures. We demonstrate that all local minima share a common structural form, partially identifying the true component centers. Specifically, each local minimum involves either fitting multiple Gaussians to one true component or fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our findings hold when the true mixture components meet a separation condition and remain valid even if the number of components is misspecified. For three-component Gaussian mixtures, we derive sharper results based on the separation scaling.

We examine the relationship between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup \( G \) of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface \( X_m \) in weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial \( W_m \). The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, employs another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface \( X_{m^t} \) within it by a dual group \( G^t \). In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner arises as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a simple proof of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this work, we generalize the study of human gait by building upon existing models in the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. This hybrid model combines a metabolic energy minimization strategy during locomotion with a non-linear description of the mass center's libration dynamics to reproduce walk-run transition behavior. Experimental results across different speed regimes show that the trajectory perimeter of the mass center is a key factor in quantifying this dynamic. The experimental procedure was conducted in collaboration with the biomedical engineering research group, basic sciences department, and laboratories at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We present a new mixed-variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that fully resolves close encounters. The method employs time regularization to maintain the stability of symplectic integrators while dynamically reducing the step size during planetary encounters. Using a high-order MVS scheme, it integrates efficiently with large time steps outside close encounters. This algorithm resolves near-collisions (within a fraction of a physical radius) while maintaining the same time step as in weakly perturbed systems like the solar system. We demonstrate its long-term stability on six super-Earths undergoing strong scattering over 50 kyr. Compared to hybrid methods like Mercury, our approach achieves superior energy conservation at equivalent computational cost.

Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where measuring the witness operator yields positive results for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In practice, due to the exponential growth of Hilbert-space dimension with system size, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is highly challenging. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and tolerates up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states needs only two local measurement settings and tolerates up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, characterized by a distinct multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We present a general method to extract multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a broad class of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can violate the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric, exhibiting a far richer multipolar structure that offers a pathway to phenomenologically constrain fuzzball models. Our numerical analysis suggests that all multipole moments are generally larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with identical mass and spin. Current measurements of black-hole candidates' quadrupole moments impose only weak constraints on fuzzballs, whereas future gravitational-wave observations of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with LISA will enhance these bounds significantly.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging task in many domains, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We examine a common scenario where edges represent either short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long-term edges are often manually defined. Human-specified edges can be costly to create and suboptimal for downstream applications. To address these challenges, we propose a model combining temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing their interactions. Since temporal attention governs feature propagation between nodes, leveraging interaction dynamics to learn this crucial component offers greater flexibility while avoiding the limitations of human-specified edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibrations in a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw) are reported. The pcw comprises two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. Models are developed and validated for transducing beam motion into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (gm) of the pcw, both far from and near the dielectric band edge. Designed for near-field atom trapping, this work establishes a framework for assessing potential thermal motion effects on optical atomic traps near pcw surfaces. Long-term objectives include achieving strong atom-mediated coupling between individual phonons and single photons in the pcw's gms, enabling quantum-level optomechanics with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors on orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms between these groups in adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The significance of these splittings arises from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of any global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings ensure that certain long exact homotopy group sequences decompose into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects suppress the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained amplitude and shape of this suppression introduce significant uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys like *Euclid* or *LSST*. In this first paper of a two-part series, we use simulations to construct a *Euclid*-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and its covariance matrix, both corrected for baryonic effects using the baryonification method from Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator for fast predictions of baryonic power suppression, enabling likelihood inference analysis for a standard $\Lambda$CDM cosmology with cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those captured in child-centered recordings, are among the most challenging audio files to process. However, developing speech processing models capable of handling such diverse conditions would be highly valuable for language acquisition studies. Researchers can use these models to analyze the quantity and quality of speech children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and assessing remediation effects. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network that classifies audio segments into vocalizations by the child wearing the recorder, other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To achieve this, we compiled diverse child-centered corpora totaling 260 hours of recordings across 10 languages.

Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. The reference to a true, yet unknown, population structure frames the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, establishes a correspondence between the groups and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, and careful selection of the smoothing parameter, which governs the density's shape and modal structure, is crucial to identify the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to interference between Standard Model predictions and higher-dimension operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes obstruct the na\"ive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the leading correction to the total diboson rate to cancel. In this scenario, precise measurements of azimuthal decay angles "resurrect" the interference, restoring sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We analyze these signatures in detail and demonstrate that EFT uncertainties from higher-dimensional operators are exceptionally well-suppressed by constructing an asymmetry variable exclusively generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating interfering higher-dimensional operator effects to the same level as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a key objective in many health and social science analyses. However, academic statistics has often discouraged data analyses aimed at causal conclusions. The emergence of "data science" offers a unique opportunity to redefine data analysis, seamlessly integrating causal inference from observational data. Like others, we categorize data science contributions into three tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (encompassing causal inference). A clear classification of these tasks is essential to address the data, assumptions, and methods needed for each. We contend that neglecting the role of subject-matter expertise in data analysis leads to widespread misconceptions about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) requires the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore is that these particles ensure extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it remains unclear what goes wrong if this condition fails. This note demonstrates that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Resolving this contradiction leads to a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general, relying neither on supersymmetry nor a specific UV completion, and assumes only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can lead to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures remains a major challenge in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable platforms to investigate the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, yet direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity \(v_{\rm c}\). We measure \(v_{\rm c}\) as a function of interaction strength and find a peak in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our results establish ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful tool for exploring the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions composed of a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) coupled to an $s$-wave superconductor. Our results show that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes are highly sensitive to the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We analyze the impact of a chiral chemical potential—the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality—on the junction's transport characteristics. Notably, we detect a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in both WSM regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two regions and strongly depends on the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has proven to be an effective and precise method for modifying surface electrical conductivity, with diverse applications. Notably, it enables voltage drop grading across high-voltage insulators, enhancing their maximum operational voltage without surface flashover. However, a key concern is the long-term stability of implantation-induced conductivity, particularly when using oxidation-prone metal species. We investigated the long-term behavior of titanium-implanted alumina's surface conductivity. Results show an initial 40% drop within weeks post-implantation, followed by a gradual 10% decrease over the subsequent year.

We introduce a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons using hidden local symmetry. The associated charge matches the skyrmion charge for smooth configurations. Singular configurations correspond to n_f=1 baryons charged under this symmetry. Here, vector mesons act as Chern-Simons fields on the quantum Hall droplet forming the n_f=1 baryon. We argue this current accurately represents the low-energy baryon current, unifying both baryon types and enabling natural transformations between them. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet arise from Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions offers a compelling way to merge anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We theoretically examine how the interplay of these effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates significant transverse Hall supercurrents, termed anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, originally developed to quantify conventional (tunneling) Josephson currents, to assess the transverse components and show their amplitudes are highly tunable via spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a distinct spectroscopic signature of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states emerge near the interface.

Following the suggestion from the Monte Carlo experiments in Jiménez (J. Turbul. 2020), which highlights the significance of dipoles in the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence, it is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by dipole concatenation. Vortices separate into small, fast-moving cores and larger, slow-moving ones, the latter resembling a 'frozen' structure within a gradually evolving 'crystal.' The kinematics of both families differ significantly, with only the former being self-similar. The latter contains most of the flow's kinetic energy, forming dipoles and streams. Mechanisms for the growth of this slow component are also discussed.

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be a powerful framework for designing quantum algorithms. Typically, the runtime of such algorithms is determined by the quantum hitting time—the duration needed for the quantum walk to locate a target vertex with high probability. In this article, we present improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, applicable to various CTQW-based quantum algorithms. Specifically, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, enhancing the hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor: from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Additionally, our methods exponentially improve the precision dependence for the continuous-time quantum walk algorithm by Chakraborty et al., which finds marked nodes in ergodic, reversible Markov chains.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered the primary EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are mainly produced by multi-body scattering in nuclear star clusters and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel: (wet) EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). Here, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially on inclined orbits and drives their migration toward the MBH—boosting EMRI formation rates in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically lack information about them—no item interactions, no user profile, and no social connections. In such cases, we still expect recommender systems to engage users immediately, encouraging them to stay and become active. This challenge falls under the new user cold-start category, which is critical for a company's growth and survival. Existing solutions either demand extra user effort, such as interviews, or rely on side information [10] like demographics, locations, or social ties. However, users may resist interviews, and side information for cold-start users is often unavailable.

Deep learning has solved many challenges beyond the reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, despite existing radio systems being well-understood with optimal algorithms available for many tasks. While some improvements have been achieved by learning individual receiver components, a superior approach is to jointly optimize the entire receiver. However, this often leads to a complex nonlinear problem, where the optimal solution is impractical to implement. To address this, we propose **DeepRx**, a fully convolutional neural network that executes the entire receiver pipeline—from frequency-domain signal streams to uncoded bits—in a 5G-compliant manner. We enhance channel estimation accuracy by carefully structuring the CNN input using both data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) to generate new inputs through mutation. A corpus of potential seeds often contains thousands of similar inputs, and this lack of diversity can result in wasted fuzzing effort due to exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To address this, fuzzers include distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds triggering the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Common practice suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of seeds improves fuzzing efficiency, which we systematically explore. We present results from over 34 CPU-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to evaluate their impact on bug discovery in real-world software.

In this paper, we examine multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be grouped such that each group shares isomorphic state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into a common template. Using this template, we design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational complexity remain unaffected by the number of agents, even under partial observation. The scalable supervisor requires no recomputation when agents are added or removed. We extend prior results to partial observation by establishing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the least restrictive supervisor at the template level. An example demonstrates the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient ENF estimation method is introduced using temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. A Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is employed, leveraging its Toeplitz structure. Additionally, this approach introduces, for the first time in ENF analysis, a non-rectangular temporal window prior to spectral estimation. Krylov matrices enable fast matrix inversion. The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in ENF estimation for 1-second power recordings. In speech recordings, it achieves high accuracy with low computational complexity.

The **direpack** package introduces a collection of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python ecosystem as a unified, cohesive toolkit. The included methods fall into three categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced-dimension spaces are provided, spanning from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M-regression. The package also offers classical and robust preprocessing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, along with dedicated plotting and cross-validation tools. Designed to align with the scikit-learn API, **direpack** ensures seamless integration into statistical and machine learning pipelines within that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely used for high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we investigated the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect in nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond. Fluorescence reduction was observed under high-power laser excitation, enhancing the nonlinearity of emission and altering the spatial frequency distribution of the image. We employed a differential excitation protocol to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the laser power, imaging resolution improved by approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Given the simplicity of the setup and data processing, we anticipate this method can enhance spatial resolution for sensing and biological labeling with solid-state defects.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the standard approach of using individual survey weights (constructed as inverses of unit inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood fails to yield asymptotically unbiased inference. We propose a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that ensures unbiased inference for hyperparameters. Our method is compared with frequentist approaches relying on numerical integration, showing that only the Bayesian approach achieves both design-unbiased estimation and population consistency. Simulations and a business establishment survey demonstrate our method's versatility across models and sampling designs. This work culminates recent efforts integrating traditional survey estimation with Bayesian modeling, bridging two rich but distinct fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS$_2$ and ReSe$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene—exhibit more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, along with novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, strong nonlinear optical effects, photogalvanic responses, and superconductivity. Unique electronic topological features, nonlinear elastic behaviors, and structural phase transitions can also arise due to low symmetry. The *Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials* special topic highlights recent experimental and theoretical advances in these materials.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was observed that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of electric birefringence above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be described by a sum of multiple exponential processes, two of which dominate. These primary processes alternate within a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also revealed two orientational relaxation processes: the first arises from rotation of the side mesogenic groups, while the second relates to motion of the main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated strong retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a key focus in these methods. A common strategy is to employ an activation function, such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, while minimizing a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this approach may trap hash bits in the wrong saturated regions of activation functions without recovery. We term this issue the "dead bits problem (dbp)." Additionally, existing quantization losses exacerbate dbp. In this paper, we introduce a simple yet effective gradient amplifier applied before activation functions to mitigate dbp.

We examine the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We explore scenarios where the triplet is stable (contributing to dark matter) or decays via Higgs mixing. The stable case is constrained by LHC disappearing-track searches and dark matter direct detection, while the decaying case faces limits from multilepton collider searches. A two-step phase transition with a stable triplet and negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection, and an unstable triplet below $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is excluded at $95\%$ confidence.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than predicted by the standard eccentric planet perturbation model (often termed "pericenter glow"). The conventional scenario assumes an initially circular, narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis \(a\), whose eccentricity rises to \(e_f\) after gas disc dispersal due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, producing a belt of width \(2ae_f\). A slight modification allows narrower belts if planetesimals start with eccentricity, possibly induced by earlier planetary perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary phase. Alternatively, primordial eccentricity might arise from disc instabilities, eliminating the need for planets altogether.

An electron is typically considered to possess only one form of kinetic energy, but could it exhibit more due to its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is well described at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we present measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using tunneling spectroscopy. We detect two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, linked to spin and charge excitations, along with the appearance of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that intensify as wire length decreases. The effective interaction strength in the wires is adjusted by varying 1D intersubband screening by over 45%.

$context$. The assembly history of the Milky Way is currently being unveiled thanks to data from the $Gaia$ mission. The globular cluster system likely followed a similarly intricate formation path. $aims$. To constrain this path, we explore the link between globular clusters and the Milky Way’s known merging events. $methods$. We combine $Gaia$'s kinematic data for nearly all galactic clusters with the largest sample of cluster ages, corrected for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyze their dynamical properties, particularly in integrals-of-motion space. $results$. We find that ~40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of a dataset's intrinsic dimension is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces *intrinsic*, an R package implementing novel, state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators for intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the package includes the two-NN, Gride, and Hidalgo models. To ensure accessibility, *intrinsic* provides high-level, intuitive functions built on efficient low-level routines. The package features models in two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category comprises the two-NN and Gride models, with functions supporting both frequentist and Bayesian inference. The second category includes Hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, enabling spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Here, two physical RC systems—based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs)—were proposed and modeled for image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Micromagnetic simulations of MSM and STNO responses to current pulses demonstrate that an RC system using a single MSM achieves outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition. Moreover, a physical RC system comprising 24 STNOs effectively solves complex nonlinear dynamic problems, as confirmed in second-order nonlinear dynamic and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a vital role in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we uncover a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items reporting a signal, the greater their collective share of traffic. This few-get-richer effect arises when items fall into limited distinct classes (e.g., left-leaning vs. right-leaning news sources) and are ranked by popularity. We analytically show this effect occurs when users click top-ranked items and exhibit heterogeneous class preferences. Through simulations, we examine how the effect’s strength varies with contextual and behavioral assumptions. We also experimentally validate our predictions in an online study. Our findings offer critical insights into misinformation spread.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as a simple yet effective method to reduce redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), enabling acceleration across platforms. However, most pruning techniques trade model accuracy for regularity, resulting in compromised inference accuracy and suboptimal on-device performance. To address this, we introduce pattern-based sparsity—a novel dimension combining pattern and connectivity sparsity—delivering high accuracy and hardware efficiency. With meticulously designed patterns, our pruning method consistently enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction across diverse DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our framework integrates pattern library extraction, selection, pruning, and weight training seamlessly. This approach naturally aligns with compiler optimizations, ensuring efficient DNN execution on mobile devices.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs significantly from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events affecting the groups differently. Creating a more closely matched control group by selecting a subset of the overall control group may reduce bias. We examine this phenomenon through simulation studies. We analyze the effect of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences approach that leverages the increase in MRM following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For our analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we developed a better-matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval indicating substantial adverse effects alongside no effect and minor beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is essential to evaluate their ability to reproduce the data. This can be achieved through visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve (1) simulating multiple replicates of the original study using the model, (2) calculating key estimates for each simulated study, and (3) comparing their distribution with the original estimate. This approach is a versatile and generally straightforward method. Here, we explore its application to time-to-event data and examine the specific scenario where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event time.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential schemes are presented. We examine how similar protocols, combining repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling pulses, enable: (i) confining and protecting quantum dynamics from decoherence, aligning with Zeno physics. (ii) analytically predicting the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state via stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstructing the spectral density of environmental noise by orthogonalizing frequency-domain filter functions driving the quantum sensor. These achievements will enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, advancing quantum science and technologies.

Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help—not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be humiliating. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster; you're speaking in public, a fate some consider worse than death. When you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. Yet at some point, we've all had to address an audience, so you must learn to overcome it. First, understand stage fright. Humans, as social creatures, are wired to care about reputation. Public speaking threatens it. Before a speech, you panic: *What if they think I'm awful or an idiot?*

I can't think of anyone who has just one interest in life, content to pursue it forever. [The way we work] Around 15% of American workers don't hold traditional full-time jobs—they're part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term 'side hustle' aligns with this ethos, as people combine multiple pursuits to earn a living. The phrase 'side hustle' originated in popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, 'hustle' described scams, but by the 1950s, 'side hustle' also referred to legitimate work. Unlike a second job driven by necessity, a side hustle offers flexibility.

Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is crafted from thousands of steel parts, the other woven from a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One imposes on the environment, the other shapes it. One is designed for nature, the other by her. Michelangelo believed raw marble held a figure yearning to break free. His chisel was his sole tool. Yet living things aren’t carved—they grow. Within our cells, the smallest units of life, lies all the information needed for function and replication. Tools also have consequences. Since the Industrial Revolution, design has been ruled by manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people say if you get nervous onstage, picture the audience naked? Like it’s supposed to help. But imagining all of you naked in 2018 feels weird and wrong. We’re trying to move past that, so we need a better way to handle stage fright. I realized what I’d really like is to look at you as much as you’re looking at me—just to balance things out. So if I had way more eyeballs, we’d all be comfortable, right?

To do two things at once is to do neither." It's a brilliant critique of multitasking, often credited to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus—though, as with many quotes, he likely never said it. What fascinates me, however, is whether it holds true. Certainly, it applies to emailing at dinner, texting while driving, or live-tweeting a TED Talk. But I’d argue that for certain important activities, doing two—or even three or four—things at once is precisely the goal. Consider Albert Einstein: in 1905, he published four groundbreaking scientific papers.

I know this may sound unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to be better humans. I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, home of Bethlehem Steel. My father, an engineer, taught me how things worked. Together, we built projects like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart we built—that's me behind the wheel, with my sister and best friend. One day, when I was about 10, he came home and announced at dinner that our next project would be... a robot. A robot.

Sustainability represents the what, where, and how of what is caught. The who and why matter most to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices—how I impact them and how they impact me. I want to understand why they fish and how they depend on the water's bounty for their livelihood. Grasping this shifts our view of seafood from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It lets us celebrate the seafood we’re fortunate to enjoy. So what do we call this? I call it restorative seafood. While sustainability is the capacity to endure, restorative means the ability to replenish and progress.

The starving orphan pleading for a second helping of gruel. The spinster fading away in her tattered wedding dress. The miser, hardened by greed, haunted by the ghost of Christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain iconic figures from the works of Charles Dickens. So profound is his legacy that it inspired its own adjective. But what makes Dickens's writing so extraordinary? His fiction brims with tension through atmospheric settings, unexpected twists, and gripping mysteries. These elements kept readers enthralled. Originally, his stories were serialized, released in affordable literary journals chapter by chapter before being compiled into books.

Shah Rukh Khan: courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the greatest achievers share. These are the brave hearts for whom failure is never an option. What seems an unconquerable sea to us is, for our next speaker, an irresistible stage she was born to command. Let’s dive into the story of fearless long-distance swimmer Bhakti Sharma, who’s making waves worldwide. Bhakti Sharma. (Applause)  

Bhakti Sharma: Imagine, under the scorching Rajasthan sun, a two-and-a-half-year-old riding a moped behind her mother, unaware of their destination. Twenty minutes later, that child finds herself submerged in water.

I'm going to discuss a technology we're developing at Oxford that we believe will revolutionize how computer games and Hollywood movies are made. That technology is human simulation—creating virtual humans with simulated bodies and nervous systems to control them. Before delving deeper, let's briefly examine current human characters in games. This clip from *Grand Theft Auto 3*, which we glimpsed yesterday, shows a well-crafted example. It remains one of the most successful games of all time.

Like many people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup in France. We watched incredible athletes deliver amazing goals in clean, engaging matches. Meanwhile, off the field, these women advocated for equal pay—or any pay at all in some countries. Obsessed, we chose a Spanish-speaking US network to watch the games live. A few matches in, a friend remarked, "Why does it feel like everything I'm seeing is ads for makeup, cleaning products, and diets?

I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's begin with a story about a culture in Micronesia during the early 1900s, known as the Yap. Their form of money is fascinating—they used limestone discs called Rai stones. Unlike our coins, the Yap didn’t physically exchange these stones because they could be enormous. The largest weighs about four tons and spans twelve feet. Instead, they simply recorded ownership. There’s a tale of sailors transporting a stone when disaster struck, and it sank into the ocean.

You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. Proving your innocence is impossible. If you maintain your innocence, you’ll likely be convicted and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others, you’ll go free. Do you lie—or risk a public hanging? This was the dilemma facing those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They were victims of supernatural paranoia, misguided religious zeal—and a justice system that prioritized repentance over truth. Salem was founded in 1626 by Puritans, English Protestants. Life there was harsh and isolated. Conflicts with Native American neighbors and French settlers were frequent.

There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to meet that demand. What if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? That’s the premise behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently in development. While we can’t yet print complex organs, simpler tissues—including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange—are already within our reach. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material to construct a three-dimensional object step by step.

Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon follows a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, oceans, atmosphere, and rocks deep underground. When plants and organisms die, much of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants absorb it again. Over millions of years, some carbon from ancient trees and sea life forms rock or fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events, such as volcanic eruptions, release trapped carbon. Human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release prehistoric carbon. Today, humans emit around 60 times more carbon than all volcanoes combined annually.
